<p>You can link or unlink certain payment methods such as a credit card, debit card, a U.S.\nbank account or PayPal Credit to your PayPal account.\nYou can also link a Cash Account to your personal PayPal account as a payment method and unlink the Cash Account by withdrawing all funds and closing it.\nPlease keep your payment method information current (e.g.\ncredit card number and expiration date).\nIf this information changes, we may update it using information and third party sources available to us without any action on your part.\nIf you do not want us to update your card information, you may remove your payment method from your PayPal account.\nIf we update your payment method, we will keep any preference setting attached to such payment method.\nYou may choose to confirm your card, so that we can verify that the card is valid and that you are the card owner.\nTo do this, we will charge $1.95 to the card.\nAfter the card is confirmed, we will immediately refund this amount to the card.</p> Receiving Funds, Holding a Balance or Transferring Funds Personal PayPal accounts <p>Money sent to your personal PayPal account cannot be held as a balance in your personal PayPal account.\nWhen you receive money to your personal PayPal account, you can:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>transfer the money via a standard transfer to your bank account linked to your personal PayPal account for free;</li>\n<li>transfer the money via an Instant Transfer to an eligible debit card or bank account linked to your personal PayPal account, subject to the fees applicable to such transfers that can be found on the Fees for Transferring Funds (for personal PayPal accounts) table and that will be disclosed to you in advance each time you initiate such a withdrawal;</li>\n<li>request PayPal to send the money to you by check (subject to a non-refundable fee of $1.50, which will be deducted from the amount of the withdrawal).\nIf you request a paper check from us, you must cash it within 180 days of the date of issuance, or we will return the funds to your linked Cash Account if you have one or hold the funds on your behalf and retain the non-refundable fee of $1.50.\nWe will not send a check to a post office box, and we will only send a check to an address once we have confirmed that it belongs to you;</li>\n<li>open a Cash Account to hold the money as a balance in your Cash Account for purchases or to transfer funds to friends and family members.\nA Cash Account is separate account from your personal PayPal account.\nIf you open a Cash Account, we will automatically link your Cash Account to your personal PayPal account.\nMore information about Cash Accounts can be found in the PayPal Cash and PayPal Cash Plus Account Terms and Conditions.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>You also cannot transfer money to your personal PayPal account to be held as a balance in your personal PayPal account.\nYou will need to open a Cash Account to hold the money as a balance in your Cash Account, which can be used for purchases or to transfer funds to friends and family members.\nMore information about Cash Accounts can be found in the PayPal Cash and PayPal Cash Plus Account Terms and Conditions.</p>\n<p>Except as provided below, any balance in your Cash Account and any funds sent to you which have not yet been transferred to a linked bank account or debit card if you do not have a Cash Account represents an unsecured claim against PayPal and is not insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC).</p>\n<p>PayPal is not a bank and does not itself take deposits.\nYou will not receive any interest on the funds held with PayPal.\nPayPal combines your PayPal funds with the PayPal funds of other PayPal users and invests those funds in liquid investments in accordance with state money transmitter laws.\nPayPal owns the interest or other earnings on these investments.\nThese pooled amounts are held apart from PayPal\u2019s corporate funds, and PayPal will neither use these funds for its operating expenses or any other corporate purposes nor will it voluntarily make these funds available to its creditors in the event of bankruptcy.</p>\n<p>If you have a PayPal Cash Card debit card as part of a Cash Account, have enrolled in Direct Deposit, or have established Goals in PayPal, such funds will have pass-through FDIC insurance as further detailed in the PayPal Cash and PayPal Cash Plus Account Terms and Conditions.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Business PayPal accounts <p>Money sent to a business PayPal account can be held directly as balance in the business PayPal account.\nThe balance functionality in your business PayPal account will differ depending on whether we have been able to verify the required identifying information that you provide to us.</p>\n<p>\n</p>\n<p>The required identifying information is:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>For sole proprietorships: name, physical address, date of birth and taxpayer identification number.\nor</li>\n<li>For other types of business legal entities: business name, business address, taxpayer identification number, and proof of business existence.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>If we have not verified the required identifying information, a balance in your business PayPal account can only be held in your business PayPal account and transferred to a linked bank account or debit card or you can request PayPal to send you the money by check (subject to a non-refundable fee of $1.50, which will be deducted from the amount of the withdrawal).\nYour balance may also be used to fund payments or money owed to PayPal, such as payments on your PayPal Working Capital account or monies owed for refunds or chargebacks.</p>\n<p>If we have verified the required identifying information, a balance can be held in your business PayPal account, transferred to a linked bank account or debit card, used to make purchases or send money to others.</p>\n<p>If you have a business PayPal account and we have verified the required identifying information that you have provided to us, you may transfer money to the balance of your business PayPal account from any bank account linked to your business PayPal account by requesting an electronic transfer from your bank account.\nIf we have not verified the required identifying information that you have provided to us, you cannot add funds to your balance in a business PayPal account.</p>\n<p>You can withdraw balance from your business PayPal account by:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>transferring it via a standard transfer to a bank account linked to your business PayPal account for free,</li>\n<li>transferring it via an Instant Transfer to an eligible debit card or bank account linked to your business PayPal account, subject to the fees applicable to such transfers that can be found on the Fees for Transferring Balance (for business PayPal accounts) table and that will be disclosed to you in advance each time you initiate such a withdrawal,</li>\n<li>withdrawing it from an ATM (automated teller machine) if you have a PayPal-branded debit card (fees may apply), or</li>\n<li>Requesting a check from us (subject to a non-refundable fee of $1.50, which will be deducted from the amount of the withdrawal).\nIf you request a paper check from us, you must cash it within 180 days of the date of issuance, or we will return the funds to your balance in your business PayPal account and retain the non-refundable fee of $1.50.\nWe will not send a check to a post office box, and we will only send a check to an address once we have confirmed that it belongs to you.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Any balance you hold in your business account represents an unsecured claim against PayPal and is not insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC).</p>\n<p>PayPal is not a bank and does not itself take deposits.\nYou will not receive any interest on the funds held with PayPal.\nPayPal combines your PayPal funds with the PayPal funds of other PayPal users and invests those funds in liquid investments in accordance with state money transmitter laws.\nPayPal owns the interest or other earnings on these investments.\nHowever, the claim against PayPal represented by your PayPal funds is not secured by these investments and you do not have any ownership interest (either legal or beneficial) in these investments.\nThese pooled amounts are held apart from PayPal\u2019s corporate funds, and PayPal will neither use these funds for its operating expenses or any other corporate purposes nor will it voluntarily make these funds available to its creditors in the event of bankruptcy.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Restrictions on transfers or withdrawals from PayPal accounts <p>To protect us and our users from loss, we may delay a withdrawal, in certain situations, including if we need to confirm that you have authorized the withdrawal or if other payments to your PayPal account have been subject to a reversal (for example, as a result of a chargeback, bank reversal or dispute by a buyer).\nIf we place a limitation on your PayPal account, a payment is subject to a hold, or your account or an associated account has a negative balance in any currency while a withdrawal from your PayPal account is pending, you will have to reinitiate the withdrawal once the limitation or hold has been lifted, or negative balance is fully paid off.</p>\n<p>We may set limits on your withdrawals, and you can view any withdrawal limit by logging into your PayPal account.\nCompleting two out of three of the following steps can help us verify your PayPal account, which may allow us to remove any withdrawal cap:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Verifying your bank account.</li>\n<li>Linking and confirming your credit or debit card information.</li>\n<li>Providing your social security number.</li>\n</ul> Managing Your Money in Multiple Currencies Holding currency other than U.S.\ndollars <p>Your balance in your business PayPal account or in your Cash Account, if you have one, may be held in currencies other than U.S.\ndollars.</p>\n<p>If you hold a balance in your business PayPal account or in your Cash Account:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>We may allow you to convert the funds to balance in another currency.\nIf you convert funds in your account, PayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including our currency conversion spread) will be used.\nWe may, at our discretion, impose limits on the amount of money you can convert or the number of conversions you can perform.</li>\n<li>You may only withdraw the funds in U.S.\ndollars.\nIn order to withdraw funds in your account held in another currency you will have to convert the currency to U.S.\ndollars, or it will be converted for you at the time of your withdrawal.\nPayPal\u2019s currency conversion rate, including our currency conversion spread, will be used.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>To receive money in a currency your account is not currently configured to accept, it may be necessary to create a balance in your business PayPal account or in your Cash Account, in that currency or convert the money into another currency.\nCertain currencies can only be received by converting the money into another currency that PayPal allows you to hold.\nIf the money is converted, PayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including our currency conversion spread) will be used.</p>\n<p>You are responsible for all risks associated with maintaining multiple currencies in a PayPal Cash Account or business PayPal account.\nYou may not manage or convert multiple currencies for speculative trading purposes, conversion arbitrage, conversion options, or any other activity that PayPal determines is primarily for the purpose of gaining or making money based on currency conversion rates.\nPayPal may hold, cancel, or reverse any transaction we determine to violate this policy.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> How we convert currency <p>If PayPal converts currency, it will be completed at the transaction exchange rate we set for the relevant currency exchange.\nThe transaction exchange rate is adjusted regularly and includes a currency conversion spread applied and retained by us on a base exchange rate to form the rate applicable to your conversion.\nThe base exchange rate is based on rates within the wholesale currency markets on the conversion day or the prior Business Day.\nor, if required by law or regulation, set at the relevant government reference rate(s).</p>\n<p>For some uses of your PayPal accounts, PayPal may determine currency conversion is necessary.\nThe applicable currency conversion spread can be found on our Fees page under the heading Currency conversion.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Currency conversion choices <p>When your payment is funded by a debit or credit card and PayPal determines a currency conversion is necessary, you consent to and authorize PayPal to convert the currency in place of your debit or credit card issuer.\nYou may have the right to have your card issuer perform the currency conversion, if applicable for that card issuer and network.\nCurrency preference selections may be presented to you in various forms, including a choice of which currency is used for the transaction, whether PayPal or your card issuer performs the conversion, or which conversion rate is used for the transaction, and may be made available individually for each card and for each automatic payment agreement.\nIf your card issuer converts the currency, your card issuer will determine the currency conversion rate and what fees they may charge.</p>\n<p>PayPal will always perform the conversion for transactions where your Cash Account balance, business PayPal account balance or linked bank account is the payment method.</p> Account Statements <p>You have the right to receive an account statement showing your PayPal account activity.\nYou may view your PayPal account statement by logging into your PayPal account.\nIf you have a Cash Account linked to your personal PayPal account, you will receive two statements: one showing all transactions in your personal PayPal account and an additional statement showing only transactions involving your Cash Account.</p> Sending Money and Buying Sending Money to a Friend or Family Member Sending money <p>You can send money to a friend or family member using the send money feature in your PayPal account (sometimes called \u201cpersonal payments\u201d or \u201cpeer-to-peer/P2P payments\u201d).\nYou can send money to a friend or family member even if they don\u2019t have a PayPal account at the time you send them money, using their email address or mobile number in any currency that PayPal supports, and you can choose which payment method you want to use.\nIf the person to whom you are sending money does not have a PayPal account, they can claim it by opening a PayPal account.\nIf they don\u2019t claim it, it will be refunded to you.</p>\n<p>We may, at our discretion, impose limits on the amount of money you can send, including money you send for purchases.\nYou can view any sending limit by logging into your PayPal account.</p>\n<p>When you send money to a friend or family member who has a PayPal account, one of two things may happen: they may accept or decline the money.\nIf they decline to accept the money, the money (including any fees you were charged) will be refunded to:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The original payment method you used for the transaction, if you used a credit card, debit card, PayPal Credit, a Cash Account, or balance in a business PayPal account as the payment method, or</li>\n<li>The balance in your business PayPal account or the balance in your Cash Account linked to your personal PayPal account if you used a bank account as the payment method and we cannot refund it to your bank account.</li>\n<li>If you do not have a Cash Account linked to your personal PayPal account, the money will be waiting for you to claim by using one of the available transfer methods under Receiving Funds, Holding a Balance or Transferring Funds for personal PayPal accounts.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>\n</p> Fees for Sending Money to Friends and Family <p>The fees applicable to sending money can be found on our Fees for Sending Money to Friends and Family page and will be disclosed to you in advance each time you initiate a transaction to send money to a friend or family member.\nIf you convert money in your Cash Account balance or in your business PayPal account balance from one currency to another before sending money, PayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including our currency conversion spread) will be used.\nIf you use your credit card as the payment method when sending money, you may also be charged a cash-advance fee by your card issuer.</p>\n<p>If you send money to a friend or family member from a third party (non-PayPal) website or by using a third party\u2019s product or service, then the third party will determine if the sender or recipient pays the fee.\nThis will be disclosed to you by the third party before the payment is initiated.</p>\n<p>You can also use the send money feature in your PayPal account to pay for goods or services.\nYou will not be charged any transaction fee for sending money to purchase goods or services as long as you choose the \u201csend money to pay for goods and services\u201d feature in your PayPal account.\nIn that case, the seller will pay a fee.\nYou must not use the \u201csend money to a friend or family member\u201d feature in your PayPal account when you are paying for goods or services.</p>\n<p>\n</p> Buying Something From, or Returning Something to, a Seller Who Accepts PayPal <p>&nbsp;</p> How to buy something <p>You can buy something from a seller who accepts PayPal, in any currency that the seller accepts and that PayPal supports using any payment method linked to your PayPal account.\nThis includes, for example:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Buying something at an online retailer\u2019s website and selecting PayPal as your payment method at checkout.</li>\n<li>Sending money to a seller for goods or services.</li>\n<li>Using your PayPal account to buy something at a seller\u2019s physical store using an electronic terminal, subject to certain limitations.</li>\n<li>Using your PayPal account to buy something at a seller\u2019s physical store using your own mobile device and a QR code, subject to certain limitations.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>If the seller you are buying from sells goods or services and that seller does not already have a PayPal account, they can claim your payment by opening a PayPal account.\nIf they don\u2019t open a PayPal account within 30 days, your purchase will be refunded.</p>\n<p>In order to manage risk, PayPal may limit the payment methods available for a transaction when you buy something.\nIn addition, payment methods may be limited for certain sellers or if you make a PayPal payment through certain third party websites or applications.</p>\n<p>When you authorize a payment to a seller who accepts PayPal, some sellers may take up to 30 days to complete the transaction.\nIn these instances, your payment may appear as a pending order in your PayPal account.\nIn that case, your authorization of the payment will remain valid until the seller completes the transaction (but no longer than 30 days).\nIf you used a debit or credit card as the payment method, your debit or credit card issuer also may show a pending authorization for a period of time until they release the hold or receive a completed transaction.\nIf your payment requires a currency conversion by us, PayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including a currency conversion spread) will be used, and may be the rate at the time the payment is processed.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Fees <p>When you buy something from a seller who accepts PayPal you don\u2019t pay a fee to PayPal.\nIf PayPal performs a currency conversion for your purchase, PayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including our currency conversion spread) will be used.\nYour debit or credit card issuer may also charge you a separate fee for non-U.S.\ntransactions.</p>\n<p>In addition you may be required to pay a fee to PayPal if you are making a purchase using PayPal Business Payments and the seller discloses to you that you, as the buyer, must pay the fee.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Payment review <p>When PayPal identifies a potentially high-risk transaction, we review the transaction more closely before allowing it to proceed.\nWhen this happens, PayPal will place a hold on the transaction and notify the seller to delay shipping of the item.\nAs a buyer, this may delay your receipt of the item you purchased.\nIf we clear the transaction, we will notify the seller and direct them to ship the item.\nIf we don\u2019t clear the transaction, we will cancel it and return the funds to you, unless we are legally required to take other action.</p>\n<p>\n</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Automatic payments <p>You can agree with a seller who accepts PayPal to use PayPal as the payment method for future purchases with that seller.\nThis agreement is between you and the seller and allows you to pay the seller on a one-time, recurring or sporadic basis.\nExamples of automatic payments that can be arranged by you either with a seller or with PayPal include those that PayPal calls a \u201cbilling agreement,\u201d \"subscription,\" \"recurring payment,\u201d \u201creference transaction,\u201d \"preauthorized transfer\" or \"preapproved payment.\"</p>\n<p>If you have a personal PayPal account, you may cancel a recurring automatic payment up to 3 <strong>Business Days</strong> before the date of the next scheduled payment from your account settings or by contacting us through the <strong>PayPal Help Center</strong>, or by calling PayPal at (888) 221-1161.</p>\n<p>Once your automatic payment is canceled, all future automatic payments under your agreement with that seller will be stopped.\nIf you cancel an automatic payment, you may still owe the seller money for the purchase or have additional obligations to the seller for any goods or services that you receive but have not paid for.</p>\n<p>If you have given advance authorization, either to a seller or to PayPal, that permits a seller to take or receive payments from your PayPal account on a regularly recurring basis (for example, every month or otherwise on a routine billing cycle), and if such payments will vary in amount, you have the right to advance notice of the amount and date of the transfer from the seller at least 10 days before the transfer is made.\nIf the seller provides the option, you may choose to receive this advance notice only when the amount of your automatic payment will fall outside a range established between you and the seller.</p>\n<p>If you have authorized an automatic payment and PayPal performs currency conversion for an automatic payment transaction, PayPal will use the transaction exchange rate (including PayPal\u2019s <strong>currency conversion spread</strong>) in effect at the time the automatic payment transaction is processed.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Refunds <p>When you buy something from a seller online using PayPal and the transaction is ultimately refunded, the money will typically be refunded to the original payment method you used for the transaction if you used a debit card, credit card, PayPal Credit, or a balance in your Cash Account or business PayPal account.</p>\n<p>If you used a bank account linked to a personal PayPal account as the payment method for the transaction, we will attempt to refund the money to your bank account.\nIf we are unable to do so, we will refund the money to your linked Cash Account if you have one.\nIf you do not have a Cash Account, the money will be waiting for you to claim by using one of the available transfer methods under Receiving Funds, Holding a Balance or Transferring Funds for personal PayPal accounts.</p>\n<p>If you used a bank account linked to a business PayPal account as the payment method for the transaction, we will attempt to refund the money to your bank account.\nIf we are unable to do so, we will refund the money to your balance in your business PayPal account.</p>\n<p>For purchases you make in a seller\u2019s store location that you paid for using your personal PayPal account and the transaction is ultimately refunded, the money will be refunded to your Cash Account if you have one.\nIf you do not have a Cash Account, the money will be waiting for you to claim by using one of the available transfer methods under Receiving Funds, Holding a Balance or Transferring Funds for personal PayPal accounts.</p>\n<p>For purchases you make in a seller\u2019s store location that you paid for using your business PayPal account and the transaction is ultimately refunded, the money will be refunded to your balance in your business PayPal account.</p>\n<p>If you used Pay with Rewards to fund your transaction, your refund will be processed back as a dollar amount: depending on your card agreement with your issuer, your issuer may or may not credit your purchase back to your reward balance.</p>\n<p>If PayPal performed currency conversion for your transaction and a refund is issued:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Within 1 day of the date of the original payment, PayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including a <strong>currency conversion spread</strong>) used at the time of the original payment will apply.</li>\n<li>Beyond 1 day of the date of the original payment, PayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including a <strong>currency conversion spread</strong>) on the date of the refund will apply.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Money will be refunded in the currency you paid.\nor if we are unable to refund in the currency you paid, in your primary holding currency.\nor we are unable to refund in your primary holding currency, then in U.S.\ndollars.</p> Payment Method Used for My Transaction <p>&nbsp;</p> Selecting a preferred payment method <p>You can choose any of the payment methods in your PayPal account as your preferred payment method.\nYou can select a preferred payment method in your account preferences on <strong>www.paypal.com</strong> or in the PayPal app.\nThere may be times when your preferred payment method cannot be used, for example, if you select a credit card that is expired.</p>\n<p>You can set separate preferred payment methods for online transactions, in-store transactions, and each of your automatic payment agreements, as described below.</p>\n<p>If you have chosen a preferred payment method, it will be shown as the primary method of payment.</p>\n<p>If no preferred payment method, it\u2019s still your choice.</p>\n<p>The availability of certain payment methods may be limited based on that particular seller or the third party website you are using to complete the transaction.</p>\n<p>If you have not selected a preferred payment method, or your preferred payment method is unavailable, we will show you available payment methods, including the payment method you used most often or most recently, at the time of transaction.\nYou can also click on the \u201cManage\u201d link to see all of your available payment methods, or add a new one, and select a payment method during the transaction.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Backup payment method <p>Certain one-time online transactions may require that a backup funding method be used in the event that your selected or preferred payment method is unavailable.\nIn those instances, the backup funding method may be displayed to you on your transaction review page, before you complete the transaction.\nNote that this only applies for one-time, online transactions, and not for in-store or automatic payments.\nIf PayPal determines currency conversion is necessary for a transaction that also requires a backup payment method, you may not be able to separately choose whether PayPal or your card issuer performs the currency conversion on your backup payment method.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Sending money to friends and family <p>When you send money to friends and family within the U.S.\nusing balance in your Cash Account linked to your personal PayPal account, the balance in your business PayPal account, or your bank account, we waive all fees, so we always show you these payment options first, even if you have a set preferred payment method for your online purchases.\nRemember, you always have the choice to select any payment method in your PayPal account by clicking the \u201cChange\u201d link on the Send Money page.\nIf you select a payment method with a fee, we will always show you the fee before you send money.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Automatic payments <p>Some sellers allow you to store PayPal as the way you pay when making purchases on their site, so you can check out faster.\nOften, this entails creating an agreement with the seller that permits them to request that we charge your PayPal account each time you make a purchase.\nTo help minimize disruptions in your automatic payments, we may update your Payment Method information.\nsee Link or Unlink a Payment Method.</p>\n<p>When you first set up an automatic payment agreement, you may have the option to set up a preferred payment method for such agreement.\nYou can review, set, or change a preferred payment method for an automatic payment agreement in your account settings on paypal.com.</p>\n<p>Your preferred payment method for an automatic payment agreement will be used for transactions with that seller.\nIf you have available balance in a linked Cash or cash Plus account, that balance may be used before your preferred payment method.</p>\n<p>If you have not set a preferred payment method for an automatic payment agreement, or if your preferred payment method for an automatic payment agreement is unavailable (for example, because it is expired or has insufficient funds) the payment method used will be in the following order, if applicable: 1.\nCash Account (if one is linked to your personal PayPal account) or balance in your business PayPal account (if we\u2019ve been able to verify the <strong>required identifying information</strong> you provide to us).\n2.\nBank account.\n3.\nPayPal co-branded debit card.\n4.\nPayPal co-branded credit card.\n5.\nDebit card.\n6.\nCredit card.\nand 7.\nE-check.\nThis is also the order of payment methods that will be used if a previously selected payment method to be used in a seller agreement is unavailable.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Bank account transfers <p>When you use your bank account as a payment method, you are allowing PayPal to initiate a transfer from your bank account to the recipient.\nFor these transactions, PayPal will make electronic transfers from your bank account in the amount you specify.\nYou authorize PayPal to try this transfer again if the initial transfer is rejected by your bank for any reason.</p>\n<p>If you use your PayPal account to pay for an item and you select your bank account as the funding method for the transaction, remember that your PayPal account is issued to you by PayPal and not your bank.\nThe terms, benefits, and protections associated with your PayPal account may vary from those that apply to your bank account.\nIf you use your PayPal account to make a purchase that exceeds the balance in your linked bank account, you could incur overdraft fees, even if you chose not to allow overdrafts with your bank.\nSimilarly, the liability limits applicable to your PayPal account may differ from those applicable to your bank account.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> E-check <p>E-check is a payment method where you use your bank account as your payment method, and the payment is not received by the recipient until the transaction is processed from the bank.\nThis process usually takes 3-5 Business Days, but this amount of time will increase if the payment is sent from a bank account located outside the United States.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Pay with Rewards <p>PayPal may allow you to redeem rewards associated with your eligible card(s) when making a purchase with your PayPal account through PayPal\u2019s Pay with Rewards program.\nPayPal may share with and receive information from your issuer about your issuer accounts to complete the redemption of your rewards when using PayPal\u2019s Pay with Rewards program.\nThe exchange of this information is necessary to complete the purchase when you select the Pay with Rewards redemption option.</p> All Pay with Rewards redemptions are subject to the terms of your card agreement with your card issuer.\nPay with Rewards is only available for eligible purchases with certain merchants, and PayPal or your issuer may limit, suspend, or terminate your ability to redeem rewards at any time in accordance with this user agreement and your card agreement.\nYour issuer determines the value of rewards redeemed through PayPal and available redemption methods (e.g., to pay for your purchase or for a statement credit).\nThere may be a delay between checkout and processing of your payment.\nOnly rewards available upon processing of your payment will be used.\nBecause your reward balance and/or transaction balance may change, whenever you request to redeem rewards for a purchase you also authorize PayPal to charge up to the full payment amount to your associated card if that happens.\nFor more information on redeeming rewards and how it works, please see About Payment Methods.\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Debit card processing <p>PayPal will process your debit or prepaid card funded transactions through either the ATM debit network or the Visa, MasterCard or Discover network.\nIf we process your debit or prepaid card through an ATM debit network, we may provide you with the opportunity to switch to a Visa, MasterCard or Discover network by changing your preferences for that debit or prepaid card through your PayPal account profile.</p> Loyalty Cards <p>If you use the PayPal application on your mobile phone, you may store loyalty card numbers or bar codes, where applicable, for certain sellers in your PayPal account.\nWhen you store your loyalty card numbers or bar codes in your PayPal account, you will earn any rewards, subject to the seller\u2019s loyalty card terms and conditions, at the time you make your payment to the merchant by presenting the stored loyalty card number or bar code to the seller at the point of sale.\nIt is your responsibility to make sure you have entered your loyalty card information correctly and that you update it as necessary.\nIt is also your responsibility to ensure that you are receiving the rewards to which you are entitled.\nPayPal is not responsible for managing your loyalty card account by offering this service and any questions about your loyalty card or associated rewards program should be directed to the seller who offers the card.</p> PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection Program <p>When you buy something from a seller who accepts PayPal, you may be eligible for a refund under PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program.\nWhen applicable, PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program entitles you to reimbursement for the full purchase price of the item plus the original shipping costs you paid, if any.\nPayPal determines, in its sole discretion, whether your claim qualifies for the Purchase Protection program.\nPayPal\u2019s original determination is considered final, but you may be able to file an appeal of the decision with PayPal if you have new or compelling information not available at the time of the original determination or you believe there was an error in the decision-making process.</p>\n<p>IMPORTANT: You may be required to return the item to the seller or other party we specify as part of the settlement of your claim.\nPayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program does not entitle you to reimbursement for the return shipping costs that you may incur.</p>\n<p>PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program may apply when you encounter these specific problems with a transaction:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>You didn\u2019t receive your item from a seller (referred to as an \u201cItem Not Received\u201d claim), or</li>\n<li>You received an item, but the item isn\u2019t what you ordered (referred to as a \u201cSignificantly Not as Described\u201d claim).</li>\n</ul>\n<p>If you believe that a transaction made through your PayPal account was not authorized by you, this type of claim is different from the Purchase Protection program, and is described below under Liability for Unauthorized Transactions and Other Errors.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> QR Code Transactions <p>If you buy something from a seller in person by using a PayPal goods and services QR code, your transaction may be eligible for PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Item Not Received claims <p>Your claim <strong>\n<em>will not</em>\n</strong> qualify for a refund under PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program for an Item Not Received claim, if:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>You collect the item in person, or arrange for it to be collected on your behalf, including if you use PayPal in a seller\u2019s physical store, except for in-person PayPal QR code goods and services transactions, or</li>\n<li>The seller has provided proof of shipment or proof of delivery.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>If the seller presents evidence that they delivered the goods to you, PayPal may find in favor of the seller for an Item Not Received claim even if you claim you did not receive the goods.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Significantly Not as Described claims <p>An item may be considered Significantly Not as Described if:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The item is materially different from the seller\u2019s description of it.</li>\n<li>You received a completely different item.</li>\n<li>The condition of the item was misrepresented.\nFor example, the item was described as \u201cnew\u201d but the item was used.</li>\n<li>The item was advertised as authentic but is not authentic (i.e.\ncounterfeit).</li>\n<li>The item is missing major parts or features and those facts were not disclosed in the description of the item when you bought it.</li>\n<li>You purchased a certain number of items but didn\u2019t receive them all.</li>\n<li>The item was damaged during shipment.</li>\n<li>The item is unusable in its received state and was not disclosed as such.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>An item may not be considered Significantly Not as Described if:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The defect in the item was correctly described by the seller in its description of the item.</li>\n<li>The item was properly described but you didn't want it after you received it.</li>\n<li>The item was properly described but did not meet your expectations.</li>\n<li>The item has minor scratches and was described as \u201cused.\"</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Ineligible items and transactions under PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program <p>Payments for the following are not eligible for reimbursement under PayPal Purchase Protection:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Real estate, including residential property.</li>\n<li>Financial products or investments of any kind.</li>\n<li>Businesses (when you buy or invest in a business).</li>\n<li>Vehicles, including, but not limited to, motor vehicles, motorcycles, recreational vehicles, aircraft and boats.</li>\n<li>Significantly Not as Described claims for wholly or partly custom-made items or items picked up in person, except for in-person PayPal QR code goods and services transactions.</li>\n<li>Donations including payments on crowdfunding platforms.</li>\n<li>Items prohibited by the PayPal Acceptable Use Policy.</li>\n<li>For Item Not Received claims, items which you collect in person or arrange to be collected on your behalf, including items bought in a seller\u2019s store location, except for in-person PayPal QR code goods and services transactions.</li>\n<li>Industrial machinery used in manufacturing.</li>\n<li>Anything purchased from, or an amount paid to, a government agency.</li>\n<li>Stored value items such as gift cards and pre-paid cards.</li>\n<li>Gambling, gaming and/or any other activity with an entry fee and a prize.</li>\n<li>Personal Payments.</li>\n<li>Payments sent using PayPal to any bill payment service.</li>\n<li>Payments made using PayPal Payouts and Mass Pay or guest checkout transactions (i.e.\nnot sent using your PayPal account).</li>\n<li>Items intended for resale, including single item transactions or transactions that include multiple items.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Transaction eligibility for PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program <p>To be eligible for PayPal Purchase Protection you must meet all of the following requirements:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Have a PayPal account in good standing.</li>\n<li>Pay for the eligible item from your PayPal account.</li>\n<li>Attempt to contact the seller to resolve your issue directly before filing a claim through the Resolution Center.</li>\n<li>Respond to PayPal's request for documentation and other information within the time requested.</li>\n<li>Open a dispute in the Resolution Center within 180 days of the date you sent the payment and follow our online dispute resolution process.</li>\n<li>Not have received a recovery or agreed to an alternative resolution related to your purchase from another source.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Our online dispute resolution process <p>If you\u2019re unable to resolve a transaction related issue directly with a seller, you must follow our online dispute resolution process through the <strong>Resolution Center</strong> to pursue a claim under our Purchase Protection program.\nYou may also file a claim (Step 2 below) by calling us and speaking to an agent.\nThe steps you must follow are described below, and if you do not follow these steps your claim may be denied:</p>\n<p>\n</p>\n<p>Step 1: <strong>Open a dispute</strong> within 180 days of the date you made the payment.\nThis might allow you to start a direct conversation with the seller regarding your issue with the transaction that may help resolve the dispute.\nIf you are unable to resolve the dispute directly with the seller, proceed to Step 2.\nWe will place a hold on all funds related to the transaction in the seller's PayPal account until the dispute is resolved or closed.</p>\n<p>Step 2: <strong>Escalate the dispute to a claim</strong> for reimbursement within 20 days after opening the dispute, if you and the seller are unable to come to an agreement, or we will automatically close the dispute.\nYou can escalate the dispute to a claim for reimbursement through the <strong>Resolution Center</strong>.\nThe seller or PayPal may also escalate the dispute to a claim at this point.\nPayPal may ask you to wait at least 7 days from the transaction date to escalate the dispute.\n</p>\n<p>Step 3: <strong>Respond to PayPal\u2019s requests for documentation or other information</strong>, after you, the seller or PayPal escalates your dispute to a claim for reimbursement.\nPayPal may require you to provide receipts, third party evaluations, police reports or other documents that PayPal specifies.\nYou must respond to these requests in a timely manner as requested in our correspondence with you.</p>\n<p>Step 4: <strong>Comply with PayPal\u2019s shipping requests in a timely manner</strong>, if you\u2019re filing a Significantly Not as Described claim.\nPayPal may require you, at your expense, to ship the item back to the seller, to PayPal or to a third party (which will be specified by PayPal) and to provide proof of delivery.</p>\n<p>Proof of delivery means:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>For transactions that total less than $750 U.S.\ndollars (or the currency threshold in the table below), confirmation that can be viewed online and includes the delivery address showing at least city/state or zip code, delivery date, and the identity of the shipping company you used.</li>\n<li>For transactions that total $750 U.S.\ndollar (or the currency threshold in the table below) or more, you must provide signature confirmation of delivery.\nIf the transaction is in a currency not listed in the table, then signature confirmation is required when the payment exceeds the equivalent of $750 USD at the PayPal exchange rate that applies at the time the transaction is processed.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>\n</p> Signature confirmation currency thresholds <p>\n<strong>Currency</strong>\n</p>\n<p>\n<strong>Transaction value</strong>\n</p>\n<p>\n<strong>Currency</strong>\n</p>\n<p>\n<strong>Transaction value</strong>\n</p>\n<p>Australian Dollar:</p>\n<p>850 AUD</p>\n<p>New Zealand Dollar:</p>\n<p>950 NZD</p>\n<p>Brazilian Real:</p>\n<p>1,750 BRL</p>\n<p>Norwegian Krone:</p>\n<p>4,600 NOK</p>\n<p>Canadian Dollar:</p>\n<p>850 CAD</p>\n<p>Philippine Peso:</p>\n<p>34,000 PHP</p>\n<p>Czech Koruna:</p>\n<p>15,000 CZK</p>\n<p>Polish Zloty:</p>\n<p>2,300 PLN</p>\n<p>Danish Krone:</p>\n<p>4,100 DKK</p>\n<p>Russian Ruble:</p>\n<p>48,000 RUB</p>\n<p>Euro:</p>\n<p>550 EUR</p>\n<p>Singapore Dollar:</p>\n<p>950 SGD</p>\n<p>Hong Kong Dollar:</p>\n<p>6,000 HKD</p>\n<p>Swedish Krona:</p>\n<p>4,950 SEK</p>\n<p>Hungarian Forint:</p>\n<p>170,000 HUF</p>\n<p>Swiss Franc:</p>\n<p>700 CHF</p>\n<p>Israeli Shekel:</p>\n<p>2,700 ILS</p>\n<p>Taiwan New Dollar:</p>\n<p>23,000 TWD</p>\n<p>Japanese Yen:</p>\n<p>77,000 JPY</p>\n<p>Thai Baht:</p>\n<p>24,500 THB</p>\n<p>Malaysian Ringgit:</p>\n<p>3,100 MYR</p>\n<p>U.K.\nPounds Sterling:</p>\n<p>450 GBP</p>\n<p>Mexican Peso:</p>\n<p>10,000 MXN</p>\n<p>U.S.\nDollar:</p>\n<p>750 USD</p>\n<p>Step 5: <strong>PayPal will make a final decision </strong>(including automatically closing any dispute or claim), in its sole discretion, based on the coverage and eligibility requirements set forth above, any additional information provided during the online dispute resolution process or any other information PayPal deems relevant and appropriate under the circumstances.</p>\n<p>Note that when you are making Digital Goods Micropayments Purchases, there are special rules that apply and that include pre-determined thresholds where we may, at our discretion, reverse the transaction without requiring you to take further action.\nWe may limit the number of automatic reversals that you benefit from, but, even if that is the case, you will still be able to follow PayPal's standard dispute resolution processes described above.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Dispute with us or your card issuer <p>If you used a debit or credit card as the payment method for a transaction through your PayPal account and you are dissatisfied with the transaction, you may be entitled to dispute the transaction with your card issuer.\nApplicable card chargeback rights may be broader than those available to you under PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program.\nFor example, if you dispute a transaction with your card issuer, you may be able to recover amounts you paid for unsatisfactory items even if they don\u2019t qualify for protection under a Significantly Not as Described claim with us.</p>\n<p>You must choose whether to pursue a dispute with PayPal under our Purchase Protection program, or to pursue the dispute with your card issuer.\nYou can\u2019t do both at the same time or seek a double recovery.\nIf you pursue a dispute/claim with us and you also pursue a dispute for the same transaction with your card issuer, we\u2019ll close your dispute/claim with us.\nThis won\u2019t affect the dispute process with your card issuer.\nIn addition, if you pursue a dispute with your card issuer, you cannot pursue a dispute/claim with us later.</p>\n<p>If you choose to dispute a transaction with PayPal and we decide against you, you can seek to pursue the dispute with your card issuer later.\nIf PayPal does not make a final decision on your claim until after your card issuer's deadline for filing a dispute, and because of our delay you recover less than the full amount you would have been entitled to recover from the card issuer, we will reimburse you for the remainder of your loss (minus any amount you have already recovered from the seller or your card issuer).</p>\n<p>Before contacting your card issuer or filing a dispute with PayPal, you should contact the seller to attempt to resolve your issue in accordance with the seller\u2019s return policy.</p> Selling and Accepting Payments Accepting Payments From Buyers for Goods and Services <p>&nbsp;</p> Receiving personal payments <p>If you use your PayPal account to receive payments for the sale of goods or services or accept donations, you must:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Pay any applicable fees for receiving the funds.</li>\n<li>Not ask your buyer to send you money using the \u201csend money to a friend or family member.\u201d If you do so, PayPal may remove your PayPal account\u2019s ability to accept payments from friends or family members.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>By integrating into your online checkout/platform any functionality intended to enable a payer without a PayPal account to send a payment to your PayPal account, you agree to all further terms of use of that functionality which PayPal will make available to you on any page on the PayPal or Braintree website (including any page for developers and our Legal Agreements page) or online platform.\nSuch further terms include the PayPal Alternative Payment Methods Agreement.\n</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> No surcharges <p>You agree that you will not impose a surcharge or any other fee for accepting PayPal as a payment method.\nYou may charge a handling fee in connection with the sale of goods or services as long as the handling fee does not operate as a surcharge and is not higher than the handling fee you charge for non-PayPal transactions.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Presentation of PayPal and Pay with Venmo <p>You must treat PayPal and/or Venmo as payment methods or marks at least on par with any other payment methods offered at your points of sale where PayPal or Venmo branded services are integrated, including your websites or mobile applications.\nThis includes at least equal or better: logo placement, position within any point of sale, and treatment in terms of payment flow, terms, conditions, restrictions, and fees, in each case as compared to other marks and payment methods at your points of sale.\nFurther, you must not present any payment method or mark upstream (or at an earlier point in the checkout experience) from the presentment of any of PayPal or Venmo services or marks.\n</p>\n<p>In representations to your customers or in public communications, you must not mischaracterize any PayPal or Venmo services or exhibit a preference for other payment methods over PayPal or Venmo services.\nWithin all of your points of sale, you agree not to try to dissuade or inhibit your customers from using PayPal or Venmo services or encourage the customer to use an alternate payment method.\nIf you enable your customers to pay you with PayPal or Venmo, whenever you display or exhibit the payment methods that you accept (either within any point of sale or in your marketing materials, advertising, and other customer communications) you agree to display the PayPal or Venmo services payment marks at least as prominently, and in at least as positive a manner, as you do for all other payment methods.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Taxes and information reporting <p>Our fees do not include any taxes, levies, duties or similar governmental assessments of any nature, including, for example, value-added, sales, use or withholding taxes, assessable by any jurisdiction (collectively, \u201ctaxes\u201d).\nIt is your responsibility to determine what, if any, taxes apply to the payments you make or receive, and it is solely your responsibility to assess, collect, report and remit the correct taxes to the appropriate authority.\nPayPal is not responsible for determining whether any taxes apply to your transaction, or for calculating, collecting, reporting or remitting taxes arising from any transaction.</p>\n<p>You acknowledge that we may make certain reports to tax authorities regarding transactions that we process.\nFor example, PayPal is required to report to the Internal Revenue Service the total amount of payments for goods and services you receive each calendar year into all of your PayPal accounts associated with the same tax identification number if you receive more than $20,000 in payments for good and services and process more than 200 transactions involving goods or services through those PayPal accounts in the same calendar year.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Your customer service information, refunds and returns policy, and privacy policy <p>You must publish customer service information with clear instructions on how your customers can contact you.\nSuch instructions must include at least: (1) one active customer service email address or active customer service URL to file tickets for assistance and/or (2) one active customer service telephone number.\nSuch information must be readily accessible for review by your customers.</p>\n<p>You must publish a refunds and returns policy.</p>\n<p>You must publish a privacy policy, where required by law.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Payment review <p>PayPal reviews certain potentially high-risk transactions.\nIf PayPal determines, in its sole discretion, that a transaction is high-risk, we place a hold on the payment and provide notice to you to delay shipping of the item.\nPayPal will conduct a review and either complete or cancel the payment.\nIf the payment is completed, PayPal will provide notice to you to ship the item.\nOtherwise, PayPal will cancel the payment and the funds will be returned to the buyer, unless we are legally required to take other action.\nAll payments that complete this payment review will be eligible for PayPal's Seller Protection coverage if they meet the PayPal's Seller Protection requirements.\nWe will notify you about payment reviews by email and/or through your PayPal account.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> In-store payments and QR code transactions <p>If you accept PayPal payments at your physical store, you must communicate the total amount of the transaction to the customer before it takes place.\nYou may charge your customer\u2019s account only for transactions that they have authorized.\nYou must also provide customers with a physical receipt if they request one.\nYou agree that any transaction that you make shall have an accurate and true description of the goods and services being purchased.</p>\n<p>If you use a QR code to accept payments in your physical store, you must use a QR code intended for goods and services transactions.\nYou must also not use QR codes intended for in-person transactions as a method of accepting payment for goods and services transactions occurring online.\nFor any buyer claims related to QR code transactions, you may be required to provide us with alternative evidence of delivery or such additional documentation or information relating to the transaction.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Marketplace sellers <p>If you\u2019re a seller on a marketplace or through a third party application where PayPal is offered, you must comply with any rules that apply to the marketplace\u2019s or the third party application\u2019s buyer protection program for sales you make through that forum.\nAny such protections may require you to take certain actions and may impact how claims are processed.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> PayPal Giving Fund <p>If you are a charity and hold a PayPal account, you may be eligible to participate in PayPal Giving Fund programs.\nPayPal Giving Fund is a Donor Advised Fund (DAF) recognized by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) under Section 501(c)(3) of the Code as a tax-exempt public charity (Federal Tax ID: 45-0931286).\nIf you meet the eligibility requirements in the <strong>Nonprofit Certification Policy</strong> and are either a \u201cPublic Charity\u201d under Section 509(a) of the Code or a \"Private Operating Foundation\" under IRS regulations, you may be automatically enrolled with PayPal Giving Fund upon acceptance of this user agreement.\nYou will receive an email from us confirming your enrollment.\nYour relationship with PayPal Giving Fund will be governed by the <strong>Nonprofit User Agreement</strong>, including receiving email communications from PayPal Giving Fund about its current and future partners about its programs.\nYou can opt out of email communications at any time in your <strong>PayPal Giving Fund profile</strong>.\nIf you don\u2019t want to be enrolled or receive donations from PayPal Giving Fund, you can opt-out at any time by <strong>contacting us</strong>.\nFor more information, please see <strong>PayPal Giving Fund\u2019s Policies</strong>.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Card not present transactions <p>Whenever a buyer uses a debit or credit card as the payment method for a transaction using their account to buy something from you as a seller, the transaction will be processed as a \u201ccard not present\u201d transaction, even if the buyer is at your store location.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Accepting preauthorized payments <p>As a seller, you can accept payments from a buyer\u2019s account through preauthorized transfers either on a one-time, regular or sporadic basis.\nThis type of transaction is sometimes called a \u201cbilling agreement,\u201d \"subscription,\" \"recurring payment,\u201d \u201creference transaction,\u201d \"pre-approved payment \" or \"automatic payment.\"</p> If you receive preauthorized payments from buyers: <p>You must:</p>\n<p>You must not:</p>\n<p>Get each buyer\u2019s prior authorization for the amount, frequency, and duration of any such payment.</p>\n<p>Restart future payments without the buyer\u2019s written authorization, if a buyer has stopped or canceled a preauthorized payment.</p>\n<p>Provide a simple and easily accessible online cancelation procedure, if buyers sign up for preauthorized payments online.</p>\n<p>Provide buyers the ability to stop any such payment up to 3 Business Days before the date scheduled for payment.</p>\n<p>Notify the buyer at least 10 days in advance of the amount and date of each preauthorized payment if the preauthorized payment will vary from the preauthorized amount or (at the buyer\u2019s option) any payment that is in an amount that falls outside of the pre-determined range.</p> Transaction Fees for Online and In-Store Payments <p>Your PayPal transaction fees depend on:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>the country of the buyer\u2019s account or the currency of their card;</li>\n<li>whether you are registered as a charitable organization and have active 501(c)(3) status.\nYour 501(c)(3) status must be documented with PayPal to receive the rates applicable to charitable organizations, and those rates will apply only after you document your status with us.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Standard transaction fees <p>The fees you pay when selling goods or services and the buyer pays using their PayPal account (or using another authorized wallet) can be found on the Standard Transaction Fees table, with the fees applicable to charitable organizations founds on the Standard Transaction Fees for Charitable Organizations table for the charitable fees.\nPlease note that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>We may adjust the fees applicable to future transactions that you process using PayPal.\nWe will provide you at least 21 days\u2019 advance notice for personal PayPal accounts and at least 5 days\u2019 advance notice for business PayPal accounts of any fee increase or the introduction of a new type of fee.</li>\n<li>If you refund a transaction to a buyer or a donation to a donor, there are no fees to make the refund, but the fees you originally paid as the seller are not returned.</li>\n<li>If you accept payments using a PayPal product (like PayPal Here or PayPal Payments Pro), the fees applicable to those products will apply to your transactions.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Micropayments fees <p>You may qualify to receive micropayments pricing for the sale of goods and services through your PayPal account, if your transactions typically average less than $10.\nIn order to qualify, you must have a PayPal account that is in good standing (for example, no limitations or negative balance), you may not be processing payments using PayPal Payments Pro and you must submit an application and have it approved by us.</p>\n<p>If your PayPal account is approved to accept micropayments, then the fees found on the Micropayment Fees table will apply to all transactions for the sale of goods or services processed through your PayPal account, instead of Standard Transaction Fees.\nIf you have multiple PayPal accounts, you must route your micropayments transactions through the appropriate account.\nOnce a transaction is processed, PayPal will not re-route the transaction through a different account.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> PayPal Payouts and Mass Pay fees <p>PayPal\u2019s Payouts and Mass Pay services let you send multiple payments in one batch to send commissions, rebates, rewards, and general payments.\nYou may be able to choose to send payments to PayPal accounts, Venmo accounts, or both.\nIn order to use these services, you must have:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>a business PayPal account in good standing and with no withdrawal limits.\nand</li>\n<li>applied for and received our permission to use these services.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>We may remove your ability to use Payouts or Mass Pay at any time if there is a higher than acceptable level of risk associated with your use of those services.</p>\n<p>The amount you will pay us for these services differs according to whether you use the Payouts service or Mass Pay service, how you send the payments, and the currency of the payment.\nThese fees can be found in the PayPal Payouts and Mass Pay Fees table.</p>\n<p>You can send money through Payouts or Mass Pay even if your receiver does not have a PayPal or Venmo account, as applicable, using their email address or mobile number.\nIf the person to whom you are sending money does not have a relevant account, they can claim it by opening one.\nIf they don\u2019t claim it, it will be refunded to you in thirty (30) days.\nPayPal is not liable for amounts sent by you in error.\nPayPal shall have no responsibility to reverse any payout payment.\n</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Your responsibility to notify PayPal of pricing or fee errors <p>Once you have access to any account statement(s) or other account activity information made available to you by PayPal with respect to your business account(s), you will have ninety (90) days to notify PayPal in writing of any errors or discrepancies with respect to the pricing or other fees applied by PayPal.\nIf you do not notify PayPal within such timeframe, you accept such information as accurate, and PayPal shall have no obligation to make any corrections.\nFor the purposes of this provision, such pricing or fee errors or discrepancies are different than Unauthorized Transactions and other electronic transfer<strong> Errors</strong> which are each subject to different notification timeframes as set forth herein.</p> Refunds, Reversals and Chargebacks <p>&nbsp;</p> General information <p>If you receive a payment for selling goods or services that is later refunded or invalidated for any reason, you are responsible for the full amount of the payment sent to you plus any fees (including any applicable chargeback fee or Dispute fee).\nWhenever a transaction is refunded or otherwise reversed, PayPal will refund or reverse the transaction from your PayPal account.\nIf a currency conversion is necessary (for example if the balance in your Cash Account or your business PayPal account for a particular currency is insufficient to cover the amount of a refund or reversal, or if the buyer paid in a different currency), PayPal will perform a currency conversion in order to refund or reverse the transaction.\nPayPal\u2019s transaction exchange rate (including our currency conversion spread) at the time the refund or reversal is processed will be used.</p>\n<p>If you refund a payment for goods or services, there are no fees to make the refund, but the fees you originally paid as the seller are not returned to you.\nThe amount of the refunded payment will be deducted from your PayPal account.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Payments that are invalidated and reversed <p>Payments to you may be invalidated and reversed by PayPal if:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>You lose a PayPal Purchase Protection claim submitted to us by a buyer, including as a result of your failure to respond in a timely manner.</li>\n<li>You lose a Venmo Protected Purchase Program claim.</li>\n<li>Your buyer pursues a chargeback related to a card-funded transaction and the transaction is not eligible for PayPal's Seller Protection.\nThe card issuer, not PayPal, determines whether a buyer is successful when they pursue a chargeback related to a card-funded transaction.</li>\n<li>You do not fulfill the transaction as promised or you cannot provide proof of shipment or proof of delivery when required.</li>\n<li>eBay decides against you under its money back guarantee program (and you haven\u2019t opted out).</li>\n<li>Our investigation of a bank reversal made by a buyer or the buyer\u2019s bank finds that the transaction was fraudulent.</li>\n<li>PayPal sent the payment to you in error.</li>\n<li>The payment was unauthorized</li>\n<li>You received the payment for activities that violated this user agreement or any other agreement between you and PayPal.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>When you receive a payment, you are liable to PayPal for the full amount of the payment sent to you plus any fees if the payment is later invalidated or reversed for any reason.\nIf the buyer paid in another currency, the full amount of that payment may be calculated in that currency, using the PayPal transaction exchange rate (including our currency conversion spread) that applies at the time the refund or reversal is processed.\nIf the balance in your Cash Account or business PayPal account doesn\u2019t cover the payment amount due plus the fees, we may use any of the payment methods linked to your PayPal account to cover the amount due.\nIf the payment methods linked to your PayPal account don\u2019t cover the amount due, this will result in a negative balance.\nA negative balance represents an amount that you owe to us, and, in this situation, you must immediately add funds to your balance to resolve it.\nIf you don\u2019t, PayPal may:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>engage in collection efforts to recover the amount due from you;</li>\n<li>take any or all action as outlined under Amounts owed to PayPal.\nor</li>\n<li>place a limitation or take other action on your PayPal account as outlined under Restricted Activities and Holds.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Dispute fees <p>PayPal will charge a <strong>Dispute fee</strong> to sellers for facilitating the online dispute resolution process for transactions that are processed either through a buyer\u2019s PayPal account or through a PayPal guest checkout.\nThe <strong>Dispute fee</strong> applies when the buyer pursues a claim directly with PayPal, a chargeback with their card issuer, or a reversal with their bank.\nThe <strong>Dispute fee</strong> will be charged at either the <strong>Standard Dispute fee</strong> rate or the <strong>High Volume Dispute fee</strong> rate.\nThe <strong>Dispute fee</strong> will be charged in the currency which you selected for the original transaction listing.\nIf the transaction was in a currency not listed in the <strong>Dispute fee</strong> table, then the fee charged will be in your primary holding currency.\nThe <strong>Dispute fee</strong> will be deducted from your PayPal account after the claim is decided.</p>\n<p>The <strong>Dispute fee</strong> amount will be determined when the dispute case is created.\nThe fee is based on the ratio of the total transaction amount of your claims compared to the total amount of your sales for the previous three calendar months.\nFor example, for a dispute raised in September, your dispute ratio will be calculated by considering your total claims to sales ratio over June, July, and August.\nYour total claims include all claims filed directly with and escalated to PayPal, except claims for <strong>Unauthorized Transactions</strong>.\nand all chargebacks from the buyer\u2019s card issuer or reversals from the buyer\u2019s bank.</p>\n<p>If your dispute ratio is 1.5% or more and you had more than 100 sales transactions in the previous three full calendar months, you will be charged the <strong>High Volume Dispute fee</strong> for each dispute.\nOtherwise, you will be charged the <strong>Standard Dispute fee</strong> for each dispute.</p>\n<p>You will <strong>\n<u>not</u>\n</strong> be charged a <strong>Standard Dispute fee</strong> for disputes that are:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Inquiries in PayPal\u2019s<strong> Resolution Center</strong> that are not escalated to a claim with PayPal.</li>\n<li>Resolved directly between you and the buyer and not escalated to a claim with PayPal.</li>\n<li>Filed by the buyer directly with PayPal as an <strong>Unauthorized Transaction</strong>.</li>\n<li>Eligible for <strong>PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection</strong> program.</li>\n<li>Claims with a transaction value that is less than twice the amount of a Standard Dispute fee.</li>\n<li>Decided in your favor by PayPal or your issuer.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>You will <strong>\n<u>not</u>\n</strong> be charged a <strong>High Volume Dispute fee</strong> for disputes that are:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Inquiries in PayPal\u2019s<strong> Resolution Center</strong> and not escalated to a claim with PayPal.</li>\n<li>Resolved directly between you and the buyer and not escalated to a claim with PayPal.</li>\n<li>Filed by the buyer directly with PayPal as an <strong>Unauthorized Transaction</strong>.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Sellers charged <strong>High Volume Dispute fees</strong> may be required to provide a remediation plan which includes an explanation of the cause of the increased dispute rate, the actions taken to reduce disputes, and the timelines for those actions.</p>\n<p>Disputes listed above may be excluded from being charged a <strong>Standard Dispute fee</strong> or a <strong>High Volume Dispute fee</strong>, but the claim itself may still be included in the overall calculation of your dispute ratio.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Chargeback fees <p>For transactions that are not processed either through a buyer\u2019s PayPal account or through a guest checkout, and where the buyer pursues a chargeback for the transaction with their card issuer, then PayPal will charge you a <strong>Chargeback fee</strong> for facilitating the chargeback process.\nThis fee with apply regardless of whether the buyer is successful in pursuing the chargeback with the card issuer.</p> The applicable chargeback fee will be deducted from your PayPal account.\nThe chargeback fee is applied as specified in the Chargeback Fee table and will be charged in the currency which you selected for the original transaction listing.\nIf the transaction was in a currency not listed in the <strong>Chargeback fee</strong> table, the fee charged will be in your primary holding currency.\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Impact of various purchase protection processes on sellers <p>You should read and understand PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program, Venmo\u2019s Protected Purchase Program, and if you sell goods and services to buyers with PayPal accounts in countries other than your own, you also should be familiar with the purchase protection available to buyers in each of those countries.\nBuyers\u2019 rights under these programs may impact you as a seller.\nYou can find information about PayPal\u2019s protection programs on the Legal Agreements page by selecting your buyer\u2019s location at the top of the page and referring to the corresponding user agreement.\nYou can find information on Venmo\u2019s Protected Purchase Program in Venmo\u2019s user agreement.</p>\n<p>If you lose a claim under PayPal\u2019s Purchase Protection program in any country, or under Venmo\u2019s Protected Purchase Program:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>You must forfeit the full purchase price of the item plus the original shipping cost.\nIn some cases you may not receive the item back.</li>\n<li>You will not receive a refund of the PayPal fees that you paid in connection with the sale.</li>\n<li>If the claim was that the item received was Significantly Not as Described, you may not receive the item back, or you may be required to accept the item back and pay for the return shipping costs.</li>\n<li>If the claim was that the item received was Significantly Not as Described and related to an item you sold that is counterfeit, you will be required to provide a full refund to the buyer and you may not receive the item back.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>If you accept PayPal payments from buyers for goods or services you sell through eBay, then you need to read and understand the eBay Money Back Guarantee program.\nUnless you opt out by calling eBay, PayPal will treat eBay\u2019s decisions in favor of your buyers under that program as a basis for reversing a PayPal payment made to you.\nIf the balance in your Cash Account or business PayPal account is insufficient to cover the amount, we may:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>place a hold on your PayPal account until sufficient funds become available in your PayPal account to cover the amount.\nor</li>\n<li>create a negative balance in your PayPal account.</li>\n</ul> PayPal's Seller Protection Program <p>&nbsp;</p> What\u2019s eligible <p>If you sell something to a buyer and the transaction is later disputed or reversed under Reversals, Claims or Chargebacks, you may be eligible for reimbursement under PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection program.\nWhen it applies, PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection program entitles you to retain the full purchase amount for debit and credit card-funded transactions.\nThere is no limit on the number of payments for which you can receive coverage.\nBy accessing the transaction details page in your PayPal account you can determine whether or not your transaction is eligible for protection under this program.</p>\n<p>PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection program may apply when a buyer claims that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>They did not authorize, or benefit from, funds sent from their PayPal account (referred to as an \u201cUnauthorized Transaction\u201d claim), and the Unauthorized Transaction occurs in an environment hosted by Paypal.\nor</li>\n<li>They didn\u2019t receive the item from you (referred to as an \u201cItem Not Received\u201d claim).</li>\n</ul>\n<p>PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection program may also apply when a transaction is reversed because of a successful chargeback by a buyer or when a bank funded payment is reversed by the buyer\u2019s bank.</p>\n<p>This section describes PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection program as it applies to you, but you should also be familiar with the Impact of various purchase protection processes on sellers.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Basic requirements <p>To be eligible for PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection, all of the following basic requirements must be met, as well as any applicable additional requirements:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The primary address for your PayPal account must be in the United States.</li>\n<li>The item must be a physical, tangible good that can be shipped, except for items subject to the Intangible Goods Additional Requirements.\nTransactions involving items that you deliver in person in connection with payment made in your physical store, may also be eligible for Seller Protection so long as the buyer paid for the transaction in person by using a PayPal goods and services QR code.</li>\n<li>You must ship the item to the shipping address on the transaction details page in your PayPal account for the transaction.\nIf you originally ship the item to the recipient's shipping address on the transaction details page but the item is later redirected to a different address, you will not be eligible for PayPal's Seller Protection.\nWe therefore recommend not using a shipping service that is arranged by the buyer, so that you will be able to provide valid proof of shipping and delivery.\n<ul>\n<li>The shipping requirement does not apply to eligible transactions involving items that you deliver in person.\nprovided, however, that you agree to provide us with alternative evidence of delivery or such additional documentation or information relating to the transaction that we may request.</li>\n</ul>\n</li>\n<li>You must respond to PayPal's requests for documentation and other information in a timely manner as requested in our email correspondence with you or in our correspondence with you through the Resolution Center.\nIf you do not respond to PayPal\u2019s request for documentation and other information in the time requested, you may not be eligible for Seller Protection.</li>\n<li>If the sale involves pre-ordered or made-to-order goods, you must ship within the timeframe you specified in the listing.\nOtherwise, it is recommended that you ship all items within 7 days after receipt of payment.</li>\n<li>Provide proof of shipment or delivery.</li>\n<li>The payment must be marked \u201celigible\u201d or \u201cpartially eligible\u201d in the case of Unauthorized Transaction claims, or \u201celigible\u201d in the case of Item Not Received claims, for PayPal's Seller Protection on the Transaction Details page.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>PayPal determines, in its sole discretion, whether your claim qualifies for the Seller Protection program.\nPayPal will make a decision, in its sole discretion, based on the coverage and eligibility requirements, any information or documentation provided during the resolution process, or any other information PayPal deems relevant and appropriate under the circumstances.</p>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Item Not Received additional requirements <p>To be eligible for PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection program for a buyer\u2019s Item Not Received claim, you must meet both the basic requirements and the additional requirements listed below:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Where a buyer files a chargeback with the issuer for a card-funded transaction, the payment must be marked \u201celigible\u201d for PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection on the Transaction Details page.</li>\n<li>You must provide proof of delivery as described below.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Intangible Goods additional requirements <p>For the sale of intangible goods and services to be eligible for PayPal\u2019s Seller Protection, the sale must meet the <strong>basic requirements</strong> and the following additional requirements: </p>\n<ul>\n<li>Integration requirements</li>\n<li>Where you have integrated a PayPal checkout product, you must be using the current version of that product if you are accepting payments directly via a website or mobile optimized website.\nor</li>\n<li>Ensure you are passing session information to PayPal at checkout if you are integrated with PayPal via a third party or if you have a native app integration.</li>\n<li>Other integration requirements may apply depending on your business model.\nWe will let you know those requirements ahead of time, if needed.</li>\n<li>Paid <strong>Standard Transaction Fees</strong> on the sale.</li>\n<li>Delivered the item and provide <strong>Proof of shipment or delivery for Intangible Goods</strong>.</li>\n<li>Provide signature confirmation when the full amount of the payment (including shipping and taxes) exceeds the amount listed in the <strong>signature confirmation threshold table</strong> (based on the currency of the payment).\nIf the full amount of the payment (including shipping and taxes) is in a currency not listed in the table, then signature confirmation is required when the payment exceeds the equivalent of $750 USD at the PayPal exchange rate that applies at the time the transaction is processed.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>&nbsp;</p> Establishing proof of delivery or proof of shipment <p>\n<strong>Physical Goods</strong>\n</p> The following is required as proof of shipment or delivery for physical goods: <p>Proof of shipment</p>\n<p>Proof of delivery</p>\n<p>Online or physical documentation from a shipping company that
